results.title: How ‘Sound of Metal’ Star Paul Raci Went From Day Jobs to Oscar Nominee
results.abstract: After decades of struggle, the 72-year-old actor finally found his breakthrough playing a deaf Vietnam vet with addiction issues — a role with parallels to his own life.

multimedia.caption: “I’ve always known what I was capable of, but nothing was happening for me out here,” Raci said of his years trying to get major roles in Los Angeles.
multimedia.copyright: Michelle Groskopf for The New York Times

results.title: Godzilla, Kong, Predator, Jason: Everybody Fight!
results.abstract: Franchise movie crossovers have a rich history of pitting adversary against adversary. Here’s a guide to some of those battles.

results.title: Since the Oscar-Nominated ‘Collective,’ Much and Little Has Changed
results.abstract: The documentary revisits a deadly 2015 fire that brought down the Romanian government and exposed the catastrophic health care system. But not all the troubles are in the past.

multimedia.caption: “The situation was so appalling that basically it should have been a big scandal in the whole of Europe,” said Alexander Nanau, the director of “Collective.”
multimedia.copyright: Ioana-Cristina Moldovan for The New York Times

results.title: When King Kong Accidentally Met Godzilla
results.abstract: The 1962 monster matchup was supposed to pit the big ape against Frankenstein’s monster. A rights issue cropped up, Toho got involved and the rest is history.

results.title: ‘Kid 90’ and the Days When Even Wild TV Teens Had Privacy
results.abstract: A documentary from Soleil Moon Frye, star of “Punky Brewster,” and a reunion of “The Real World” remind us that Gen X didn’t curate themselves for mass consumption.

results.title: Larry McMurtry, Novelist of the American West, Dies at 84
results.abstract: In “Lonesome Dove,” “The Last Picture Show” and dozens more novels and screenplays, he offered unromantic depictions of a long mythologized region.

multimedia.caption: The author Larry McMurtry in 1978 at home. In a career that spanned more than five decades, he wrote more than 60 novels and screenplays.

results.title: Bertrand Tavernier, 79, French Director With Wide Appeal, Dies
results.abstract: He was a regular on the world’s film festival circuit with movies like “Death Watch,” a science-fiction thriller, and “’Round Midnight,” about a jazz musician.

multimedia.caption: The director Bertrand Tavernier at the Rome Film Festival in 2019. He won a best director award at Cannes for “A Sunday in the Country.”

results.title: A Tiny Icelandic Town Campaigns for the Oscars
